name: hydrazinecarboxamide, n-phenyl-
Reason: 1,3-dioxolane has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit we can compare to is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The additional functional groups and structural features in hydrazinecarboxamide will affect its melting point: (1) Two phenyl groups, which could each add approximately +20 due to the increase in molecular weight and rigidity of the structure; (2) The tertiary butyl group (C(C)C) is a bulky group which could add about +10 due to steric hindrance and increasing the molecular volume; (3) The piperidine ring (N1CCCC1) and 1-ethyl-4-methylenepiperidine moiety may both add roughly +20 each due to adding more rigid ring structures and making the molecule more compact; (4) The hydrazine group (N) can participate in hydrogen bonding, adding about +20. Summing these modifications gives us an estimated melting point shift.
